unnormalised: Property prices in Mumbai saw a 10% increase in Q3 2024, according to a report by Knight Frank. The average price per sq ft in Bandra touched Rs. 75,000, a significant jump from Rs. 68,000 last year. Demand is particularly high for 2BHK flats in areas close to railway stations.
normalised: Property prices in Mumbai saw a ten percent increase in Q three two thousand and twenty four, according to a report by Knight Frank. The average price per square foot in Bandra touched rupee seventy five thousand, a significant jump from rupee sixty eight thousand last year. Demand is particularly high for two B-H-K flats in areas close to railway stations.

unnormalised: "We're seeing a lot of interest from first-time home buyers," said Mr. Sharma, a local real estate agent. "Many are willing to pay upwards of Rs. 1.5 crore for a decent apartment. The loan interest rates, though, are still a concern." The registration of new properties also increased by 15% in the same period, with over 12,000 units registered in September alone.
normalised: "We're seeing a lot of interest from first-time home buyers," said Mister Sharma, a local real estate agent. "Many are willing to pay upwards of rupee one point five crore for a decent apartment. The loan interest rates, though, are still a concern." The registration of new properties also increased by fifteen percent in the same period, with over twelve thousand units registered in September alone.

unnormalised: The Maharashtra governmentâ€™s recent decision to reduce stamp duty to 3% for properties valued up to Rs. 50 lakh is expected to further boost the market. Experts predict that this momentum will continue into Q4, especially with Diwali just around the corner, a traditionally auspicious time for property purchases. New projects are launching too, in areas like Navi Mumbai, with starting prices at Rs 6000/sq ft.
normalised: The Maharashtra government's recent decision to reduce stamp duty to three percent for properties valued up to rupee fifty lakh is expected to further boost the market. Experts predict that this momentum will continue into Q four, especially with Diwali just around the corner, a traditionally auspicious time for property purchases. New projects are launching too, in areas like Navi Mumbai, with starting prices at rupee six thousand per square foot.
